TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed EventLevel extends System.Enum

Docs.summary: Identifies the level of an event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The level signifies the severity of an event. Lower severity levels encompass higher severity levels. For example, Warning includes the Error and Critical levels, which are higher in severity.
## Examples The following example shows how to use the EventLevel class to specify event levels. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventSource> class.
[!code-vb[ETWTrace#5](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_1.vb)] [!code-cs[ETWTrace#5](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_1.cs)]
[!code-vb[ETWTrace#6](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_2.vb)] [!code-cs[ETWTrace#6](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_2.cs)]
[!code-vb[ETWTrace#11](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_3.vb)] [!code-cs[ETWTrace#11](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_3.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventLevel Critical = int32(1)

Docs.summary: This level corresponds to a critical error, which is a serious error that has caused a major failure.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventLevel Error = int32(2)

Docs.summary: This level adds standard errors that signify a problem.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example shows how to use the Error field to identify an error message. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventSource> class.
[!code-vb[ETWTrace#5](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_1.vb)] [!code-cs[ETWTrace#5](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventLevel Informational = int32(4)

Docs.summary: This level adds informational events or messages that are not errors. These events can help trace the progress or state of an application.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example shows how to use the Informational field to identify an informational message. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventSource> class.
[!code-vb[ETWTrace#6](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_2.vb)] [!code-cs[ETWTrace#6](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_2.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventLevel LogAlways = int32(0)

Docs.summary: No level filtering is done on the event.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventLevel Verbose = int32(5)

Docs.summary: This level adds lengthy events or messages. It causes all events to be logged.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example shows how to use the Verbose field to identify a verbose message. This code example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventSource> class.
[!code-vb[ETWTrace#11](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_3.vb)] [!code-cs[ETWTrace#11](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.diagnostics.tra_4_3.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventLevel Warning = int32(3)

Docs.summary: This level adds warning events (for example, events that are published because a disk is nearing full capacity).
